Cost of housing to undergo 9% increase
Rent charges for Universityowned housing will increase by
an average of nine percent next
year, University officials said yesterday.
"I think it's rock bottom—the
absolute minimum that could
have been expected," said Dean
of Students Jakie Hall of the
hike.
Hall said the increase was announced to the Trustees for
"their information, not approval" at the Board's full meeting
last Friday.
The nine percent figure was arrived at after a comprehensive analysis of housing costs conducted by the Dean of Student in
conjunction with the Director of
Housing and the Director of

Plant Management.
This review adhered to the
"zero budgetary policy" set
down by the administration for
evaluating allocations for the
next fiscal year. Said .Hall, "We
priced the whole situation out,
starting from zero and building
up."
The Dean said some increase in
rent fees was expected, though
the recent jump in inflation necessitated a more substantial hike
than had been anticipated.
"It's not a purely inflationary
increase," he explained. "Under
normal circumstances the increase would not have been this
high, but we did expect one."
Betty Miller, business manager
for the Dean of Students, said

that while the rent increase for
Wolman and McCoy Halls and
the University's Homewood Apartments will average nine percent, feed for the Alumni Memorial Residences will vary
slightly above that figure.
Though the price for a double
room in the dorms will increase
the average nine percent to $790
for the academic year, the price
for a single will go up 13 percent
to $990. "The differential between the single and double
rooms price throws the percentage off for the dorms," she explained.
She said, though, that the rent
increase, "as computed for all
Univeristy housing," will still amount to nine percept.;

Symposium selections process challenged
The Student Council Selections Committee proposed Wednesday night a revision of the
selections process for the Milton
S. Eisenhower Symposium
topics.
The Council narrowly approved placing the proposed procedural changes on a student referendum next week.
The proposed change, presented to the Council by Selections Committee head Andy
Fredman, will mean less influence on the part of the student
body in the selection of the
Symposium topic.
Under the proposed system,
the Selections Committee would
make an initial screening of the
proposals, and then send at least
80 per cent of them to a student
referendum. From the top three
vote-getters, the Selections Committee would choose the topic,
unless one of the Symposium
proposals receives a clear majority.
Under the system presently
employed, the Selections Committe narrows down the field of
proposals and undergraduates
then select a topic through the
referendum, with a plurality sufficient to win.
The move to initiate a change
in the selection mechanism, according to Fredman, was "not a
reaction to this year's Symposium."
"Perspectives" has come under
criticism for -its execution as well

as the very nature of the topic.
Fredman said that the Selections Committee's move was not
prompted by any one thing in
particular, although he admitted
that this past year's Symposium
"might have in some small way
affected the decision."
Fredman said. that he personally intiated the move and stated
that the idea was the result of his
observations of the Symposium
for the last four years and that

no outside forces influenced his
decision.
Combination
Fredman asserted that the proposed change is a combination of
last year's system and. that used
'n the six years before. Under
that process, the Selections Committee made the selection, which
required only the approval of the
SC.
The Selections Committee's
proposal to the Council Wednes-

day night restricts the student
body's influence over the selection even more than the final
draft adopted by the Council.
Proposal
In the original proposal, the
Selections Committee did not
stipulate that a majority of votes
would necessarily mean a topic
would be selected and the Selections Committee would choose
from the six top vote-getters

Hopkins Hundreds $30 million shy of goal
By SUE EYRICH
The Hopkins Hundreds campaign is $30 million shy of its
$100 million goal as it enters its
third and final year cf fund-rai-

Charles Trimble

sing.
President Muller announced
last week that the drive has amassed $70,124,890 in gifts and
pledges and expressed optimism
that the $100 million level would
be reached.
"I would have hoped to have
raised $75 million by this time,"
said Muller,"but I am still confident that we will reach our goal."
He said, though, that he expects "the last $30 million to be
.he toughest."
Muller attributed the campaign's succes in part to the present balanced state of the University budget and the thorough publicity and solicitation efforts of
the fund drive's representatives.
Charles Trimble, director of
the campaign, said that the University trustees have generated
the largest response. "They've
contributed more than $12 mil-

lion, which is unprecedented at
Hopkins," he said.
Trimble said that much of the
campaign's emphasis in soliciting
funds has been on "deferred"
gifts in the form of trusts, bequests, and pledges, unlike the
Annual Roll Call which requests
immediate cash payments.
He expressed the hope that the
Roll Call's solicitations will not
be decreased as the Hopkins Hundreds campaign 'approaches its
goal. "Traditionally, when universities and colleges have capital
campaigns, the Annual Roll Call
may decrease temporarily. However, it usually zooms after the
payment of the capital campaign."
In its final phase, the fund-raising drive will concentrate on alumni donations. Said Muller,
"...to put it very simply we are
asking every single person ever as-

socated with Johns Hopkins to
make that extra once-in-a-lifetime gift that will nourish the
Johns Hopkins University
through a second century."
Trimble said, "the alumni are
clot expected to give $30 million."
"Instead," he continued,"we
will continue to solicit large gifts
through the entire campaign."
In addition to the endowment
of named professorships at the University, the $100 million will
facilitate the renovation of patient beds, clinics, and laboratories at the Hospital Included in
this is the proposed improvement
of the University-wide libraries
and endowments for student support.

will be given on Commemoration
Day 1976, even if the S100 million goal has not been attained.

Higham named to John M. Vincent Chair in History
Professor John Higham has
been named to the John Martin
Vincent Chair in History, President Muller announced recently.
Higham, who obtained his
bachelor's degree from Johns
Hopkins in 1941, holds a master's and doctoral degrees from
the University of Wisonsin. A nationally known specialist in the
History of the American culture
and society in the 19th and 20th
centuries, he joined the Johns
Hopkins faculty in 1971.
He is the author of a number
of influential works, including
Strangers in the Land, which
won the Dunning Prize of the
American Historical Association
and marked the beginning of an

important shift in the historical
analysis of immigration to the
United States.
Another of his works, entitled
From Boundlessness to Consolidation and published in 1969,
led to major reconsiderations in
the area of 19th-century American intellectual history. His most
recent work is entitled Send
These to Me: Jews and Other Immigrants in Urban America, to
be published this spring.
Of his appointment to the
Chair, Dr. Higham said that it
will not alter his position on the
faculty or his duties in any way.
"It's primarily an honor," he

noted. "I take it simply as a compliment. It's a certain assurance
of the faculty and administration's confidence in me."
"It has no temporal or material value," he added.
Higham has held offices in a
number of professional organizations. In 1973-74 he was president of the Organization of American Historians. From 1970
to 1974 he was a member of the
Council and Executive Committee of the American Historical
Association and last year he
headed its committee on
research. He was elected to the
American Academy of Arts and

Sciences in 1972 and in 1972-73
was a Phi Beta Kappa Visiting
Scholar. Last summer, Dr. Higham was the visiting lecturer on
American History at the American Studies Seminar in Kyoto,
Japan.
The John Martin Vincent
Chair was established in 1939 under the will of John Martin Vincent, a former Johns Hopkins
professor of history.
Higham is one of several
professors to be appointed to an
endowed Chair this year. Most
recently, Dr. Donald Howard was
appointed to the Donovan Chair
in English.

By RUSS SMITH
and

1. An alternative to the high book prices
at the JHU Bookcenter is Allen's Book
Shop, located at thirty Third and University Avenue.
The Bookshop, which opened last September 14, offers books for lower prices
than any area book store. The owner,
Allen Atwood, was the former manager
of John Gach's used book store on Greenmount Avenue, as was often mistaken for
John Gach himself.
Atwood, a longtime resident of Baltimore, is a book collector and former
teacher. Although he admits that it is difficult to make a living selling used books,
he is committed to the idea of a cheap
book store. He is able to sell his books at
low prices for a variety of reasons, the
most significant of which is the high turnover rate of his books. Also, he buys from
cheap sources and obtains remainders
from book publishers. And he adds,"Be- '
sides, I like playing Santa Claus."
Atwood continues: "We have to face
the facts, nine out of ten times, new
books are not available in area book
stores." To alleviate this situation, he intends to initiate a book ordering service.
Maintained on a low profit margin, in
comparison to the standard book ordering service, it is essential that many facilitate this utility. For a small service
charge, Atwood can obtain sets of books
at wholesale prices for his customers.
The Hopkins community is responsible
for much of the shop's business. Atwood
said that business decreased noticeably
during the intersession period.

Always expanding his stock, Atwood is
looking for books that are commonly
used at universities. He is increasing his
science collection and buys regularly
from the Library of Congress. He hopes
that further categorization and a wider
selection of books, as well as his ordering
service, will attract more area students.
Allen's Bookshop is an unpretentious
and pleasant alternative to the Hopkins
Bookcenter. For inexpensive hard-bound
and paperback books, stop in at Allen's.

By ALAN HIRSCH
With faculty salaries rapidly becoming
a vital issue on most campuses across the
country, faculties are considering unionizing more and more in order to insure that
they are given fair financial compensation.
Locally, teacherk at the University of
Maryland are actively pursuing the possibility. Before they can move to collectivized bargaining, the State Legislature must
approve the move; and there are several
bills currently pending in the Legislature
which would allow for unionization
there.
At Harvard, even, the possibility exists,
as the faculty has organized a committee
to investigate the feasibility of such action.
At Hopkins, however, where the average faculty salary has dropped in terms of
real dollars for the last four years, all
signs indicate that there is little interest in
unionization, let alone any action being
undertaken toward that end.

greivances.

people here. That's one of the reasons I
